column1: Northwich is a town and civil parish in the unitary authority of Cheshire West and Chester and the ceremonial county of Cheshire
column2: England. It lies in the heart of the Cheshire Plain
column3: at the confluence of the rivers Weaver and Dane. The town is about 18 miles (29 km) east of Chester
column4: 15 miles (24 km) south of Warrington
column5: 19 miles (31 km) south of Manchester and 12 miles (19 km) south of  Manchester Airport. The population of the civil parish was 19
column6: 924 in 2011 and for the wider built-up area (which also covers parts of several other civil parishes) was 47
column7: 421. Northwich was named as one of the best places to live in the United Kingdom by The Sunday Times in 2014.The area around Northwich has been exploited for its salt pans since Roman times
column8: when the settlement was known as Condate. The town has been severely affected by salt mining
column9: and subsidence has historically been a significant problem. Mine stabilisation work was completed in 2007.

column1: == History ==
=== Early history ===
During Roman times
column2: Northwich was known as Condate
column3: thought to be a Latinisation of a Brittonic name meaning "Confluence". There are several other sites of the same name
column4: mostly in France; in Northwich's case
column5: it lies at the junction of the rivers Dane and Weaver.Northwich can be identified through two contemporary Roman documents. The first of these is the Antonine Itinerary
column6: a 3rd-century road map split into 14 sections. Two of these sections
column8: mention Condate: Route II ("the route from the Wall to the port of Rutupiae") and Route X ("the route from Glannoventa to Mediolanum"). The second document is the 7th-century Ravenna Cosmography. This document refers to Condate between the entries for Salinae (now Middlewich
column11: at the time the capital of the Corieltauvi tribe.The Romans' interest in the Northwich area is thought to be due to the strategic river crossing and the location of the salt brines. Salt was very important in Roman society; the Roman word salarium
column14: but the exact link is unclear. It is also theorised that this is the basis for the modern word salary. Another theory is that the word soldier itself comes from the Latin sal dare (to give salt).  See History of salt for further details. There is archaeological evidence of a Roman auxiliary fort within the area of Northwich now known as "Castle" dated to AD 70.  This and other northwestern forts were built as the Romans moved north from their stronghold in Chester.The association with salt continues in the etymology of Northwich. The "wich" (or wych) suffix applies to other towns in the area: Middlewich
column15: Nantwich and Leftwich. This is considered to have been derived from the Norse
column18: and is associated with the more traditional method of obtaining salt by evaporating sea water. Therefore
column19: a place for making salt became a wych-house; Northwich was the most northern of the -wich towns in Cheshire.

column1: === Medieval to early modern ===
The existence of Northwich in the early medieval period is shown by its record in the Domesday Book:

In the same Mildestuic hundred there was a third wich called Norwich [Northwich] and it was at farm for £8.There were the same laws and customs there as there were in the other wiches and the king and the earl similarly divided the renders.
... All the other customs in these wiches are the same.
This was waste when (Earl) Hugh received it; it is now worth 35s.
The manor of Northwich belonged to the Earls of Chester until 1237 when the family line died out. Subsequently
column2: Northwich became a royal manor and was given to a noble family to collect tolls in exchange for a set rent.That salt production continued throughout the centuries and can be seen through John Leland's description of the town in 1540:

column1: Northwich is a pratie market town but fowle
column2: and by the Salters houses be great stakes of smaul cloven wood

column1: to seethe the salt water that thei make white salt of.
Between 1642 and 1643
column2: during the English Civil War
column3: Northwich was fortified and garrisoned by Sir William Brereton for the Parliamentarians.The salt beds beneath Northwich were re-discovered in the 1670s by employees of the local Smith-Barry family.  The Smith-Barrys were looking for coal
column4: but instead discovered rock salt
column5: in the grounds of the family home

column1: === 19th century ===
During the 19th century it became uneconomical to mine for the salt. Instead hot water was pumped through the mines
column2: which dissolved the salt. The resultant brine was pumped out and the salt extracted from the brine. This technique weakened the mines and led to land subsidence as they collapsed. Subsidence affected the town and the surrounding landscape. For example
column3: collapses in 1880 formed Witton Flash as the River Weaver flowed into a huge hole caused by subsidence. Subsidence also allegedly accounts for many old timber-framed houses in the town centre
column4: which were better able to withstand the movement of the ground. Some houses were built on a base of steel girders that could be jacked up to level the house with each change in the underlying ground. The town's historical link with the salt industry is celebrated in its museum
column5: which is today in the old workhouse.

column2: John Brunner and Ludwig Mond founded Brunner Mond in Winnington and started manufacturing soda ash using the Solvay ammonia-soda process. This process used salt as a main raw material. The chemical industry used the subsided land for the disposal of waste from the manufacture of soda-ash. The waste was transported through a network of cranes and rails to the produce limebeds. This was a dangerous alkaline substance and caused the landscape to be abandoned as unusable.

column1: == Modern development ==
In 1975 Marbury Country Park was the first area to be reclaimed from dereliction and has become a popular recreational area. In 1987 more land was reclaimed to form Furey Wood and over later years
column2: Cheshire County Council's Land Regeneration Unit reclaimed what is now known as Anderton Nature Park
column3: Witton Flash
column4: Dairy House Meadows
column5: Witton Mill Meadows
column6: and Ashton's and Neumann's Flashes. The area now extends to approximately 800 acres (323 ha) of public space known as Northwich Community Woodlands.In February 2004 a £28 million programme to stabilise the abandoned salt mines underneath Northwich was begun.  The work was funded by the English Partnerships through its Land Stabilisation Programme
column7: introduced to resolve issues associated with unstable mines around England.

column1: The four mines identified for work were Baron's Quay
column2: Witton Bank
column3: Neumann's and Penny's Lane. These mines were chosen because their subsidence was causing problems for the town centre. The stabilisation plan involved removing millions of litres of brine from the four mines and replacing it with a mixture of pulverised fuel ash (PFA)
column4: cement and salt. The project was completed in late 2007.The old Magistrates Court and Memorial Hall have been demolished and been replaced by Memorial Court
column5: a £12.5 million cultural and leisure centre

column1: The £80 million Barons Quay Development
column2: a retail and leisure complex will see the creation of more than 300
column3: 000 square feet (28
column4: 000 m2) of shopping space
column5: together with a new Asda superstore with a petrol filling station
column13: new public spaces and parking. Construction started in late 2014. The cinema opened in December 2016.A major fire occurred at the Northwich Outdoor Market on 3 January 2020.

column1: == Governance ==
At the time of the Domesday survey (1086) Northwich was in the hundred of Middlewich
column2: but by the 14th century it had become part of the Northwich hundred. This probably happened during the reorganisation of the Hundreds in the 12th century.  Northwich has been described as a borough from around 1288
column3: though there is no surviving borough charter.Northwich originally constituted an area of only 13 acres (53
column4: 000 m2) at the confluence of the Rivers Weaver and Dane. The much larger township of Witton cum Twambrooks lay to the east
column5: Leftwich to the south
column7: and Winnington to the north-west.The manor of Northwich was granted to the Stanley family
column9: and stayed in the family's hands until the late 18th century. A local board was founded on 26 June 1863 after the Local Government Act 1858 and it purchased the manor from Arthur Heywood Esq. in 1871. In 1875
column10: the local boards for Northwich and Witton cum Twambrooks were amalgamated
column11: and the resultant district was further extended in 1880 to include the whole of Castle Northwich and parts of Hartford
column12: Winnington and Leftwich. On 10 September 1894 these areas were united as the civil parish of Northwich
column13: served by Northwich Urban District Council.The town was further enlarged in 1936 by the addition of parts of Winnington
column17: and again in 1955 when parts of Davenham
column19: Rudheath and Whatcroft were added.The Local Government Act 1972 replaced the Urban District Council of Northwich with a new district (later borough) council: Vale Royal. Vale Royal covered areas previously covered by Northwich UDC (Urban District Council)
column21: Winsford UDC and parts of Runcorn RDC. Northwich Town Council now has the powers of a parish council and is now made up of five main districts of Leftwich

column1: Vale Royal Borough Council was abolished on 1 April 2009
column2: and Northwich now falls within the new unitary authority of Cheshire West and Chester.

column1: Between 1885 and 1983 Northwich gave its name to a parliamentary constituency. Northwich was also split between the Tatton and Eddisbury constituencies until the formation of Weaver Vale for the 1997 general election. The seat is currently held by Mike Amesbury (Labour).The town coat of arms features the Latin motto "Sal est Vita" meaning "Salt is Life"
column2: which can be seen on the town's crest of arms. The town is twinned with Dole in France.

column1: == Geography ==
Northwich is situated in the Cheshire Plain at coordinates 53°15′20″N 2°31′20″W (53.255
column2: −2.522). The town is between 15 and 35 metres (49 and 115 ft) above mean sea level. Northwich is surrounded by the following civil parishes
column3: starting due north and proceeding in a clockwise direction: Anderton with Marbury
column4: Marston
column5: Wincham

column1: Two rivers meet in the town centre
column2: the Weaver and the Dane. The town is surrounded by undulating pasture. Subsidence and the collapse of underground saltworks has created flashes and there are also local meres – for example
column3: to the north is Budworth Mere and to the north-east is Pick Mere.

column1: === Climate ===
Northwich experiences a temperate oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb )
column2: with cold winters and warm summers
column3: and precipitation all year round. The highest temperature on record is 36.7 °C (98.1 °F) in July 1868 and the lowest is −22.5 °C (−8.5 °F) in January 1982. The highest pressure ever recorded
column4: since records began in 1850
column5: is 1
column6: 050 hPa (31 inHg) reported on 19 January 2020. The lowest is 949 hPa (28.0 inHg) on 17 December 1989.

column4: 046 (50.4%) females. There were 8

column1: == Economics ==
Northwich has been described as having a market since at least 1535
column2: when it was described as a market town by Leland
column3: but there is no surviving charter. The town still has a market today
column4: which is earmarked for refurbishment as part of the Northwich Vision plans.The town's economy was dominated by the salt industry. However
column5: a list of tolls for goods crossing over Northwich bridge in 1353 shows goods coming into the town
column6: including a wide range of carcasses
column16: and millstones. This indicates a much wider economic base to medieval Northwich than just the salt trade. Documentary evidence also exists for a mill from 1332 onwards and there is evidence for more than one mill from 1343.Allied to the extraction of salt was a bulk chemical industry
column17: which became concentrated at the three ICI sites at Winnington
column18: Wallerscote and Lostock. The first industrially practical method for producing polythene was accidentally discovered at the Winnington Laboratory in 1933.Bakers Frank Roberts & Sons have been associated with the town since 1887 and continues to be based near the town at Rudheath on the A556. Two of Frank Roberts & Sons's three main business divisions
column19: Roberts Bakery and The Little Treats Co
column20: are based in Northwich and Aldred's The Bakers
column22: Derbyshire.There are many contemporary major employers in nearby Rudheath and Hartford.

column2: Northwich had 13
column3: 928 people aged between 16 and 74. Of these

column1: == Culture and community ==
The town has two key annual events. Over the August Bank Holiday weekend
column2: Northwich Festival is held at Moss Farm Sports Complex
column3: featuring four days of music and sport. Since 2011
column4: the town's Medieval Festival has been staged in Verdin Park.

column1: Northwich Memorial Hall was opened in 1960 but closed for redevelopment in 2013
column2: to be replaced by the Memorial Court Facility
column3: opened in 2015. It hosted a range of activities
column4: including the Purple Cactus Comedy Club.The Harlequin Theatre produces six plays each year
column5: and it is also the home of Northwich Folk Club (which has run continuously since 1977).The Regal cinema closed in 2007 and was demolished. A cinema in the Barons Quay development opened in 2016.Northwich has two local newspapers: the Northwich Guardian
column8: published by Trinity Mirror. Radio station Shout Radio broadcasts online and covers the mid-Cheshire area including Northwich (territory previously covered by the now defunct Cheshire FM).

column1: Northwich musicians include Steve Hewitt
column2: drummer with Placebo
column3: which provided a song for the soundtrack to the film Cruel Intentions
column4: and Tim Burgess from the Charlatans
column5: a band once managed by Steve Harrison from the town's Omega Music record store.Local horror author Stuart Neild's first novel
column7: was set in the salt mines that run underneath Northwich
column8: combining fact with supernatural fiction. Neild's novels featuring Northwich and other North West locations. A Hollywood film and television series was in development.

column1: == Sport ==
Northwich is the home of three non-league football teams: Witton Albion
column2: Northwich Victoria and 1874 Northwich. In May 2018 the Cheshire FA announced plans for a £70m development near Northwich
column3: modelled on St George's Park National Football Centre. The facility would include two FIFA-standard pitches with a 1000-seat stadium
column4: 3G pitches
column5: six grass pitches
column6: full medical facilities and a hotel/spa.The town has two rugby union sides Northwich RUFC and Winnington Park.

column1: The area also boasts several amateur cricket clubs
column2: including Winnington Park CC
column3: Davenham CC
column4: Weaverham CC
column5: Northwich CC and Hartford CC. Northwich also has a successful competitive swim team – Northwich Swimming Club
column6: first formed in the late 19th century.

column1: Northwich Rowing Club was formed in 1875 in Northwich and continues to row on the River Weaver
column2: producing Olympic and international rowers such as Matt Langridge. The club has its own boat and clubhouse located by The Crescent and holds three events every year
column3: the Autumn Head in November
column4: the Spring Head in April and the Regatta in May. In 2015 the club was the first rowing club from the north of England to win the Junior Coxed Quad Sculls at the Head of the River Fours on the tideway in London. Club crews have also competed in the Henley Royal Regatta
column5: with a crew seeded in 2015 for the first time in the club's history. The club also has a large junior section taking rowers on from age 12.The Northwich Festival
column6: held at Moss Farm Sports Complex each August includes the UK Strongman-North Competition.The town also has a long-standing cycling club
column8: its members included ex-pro and ITV commentator Paul Sherwen and domestic rider Alan Kemp. The club competes in road racing
column10: track racing and off-road. The club promotes three road races
column11: a series of circuit races in June at Oulton Park
column12: the Cat and Fiddle hill climb
column14: the club has promoted the Cheshire Classic women's cycling road race
column15: held every April. Part of British Cycling's National Road Race Series
column16: it is the longest running race on the women's national calendar. Previous winners include Dame Sarah Storey
column19: Nicole Cooke and Mandy Jones.The first known swimming baths in Northwich was the Verdin Baths
column21: presented by Robert Verdin in commemoration of the Jublilee of Queen Victoria in 1887. It consisted of a 60-by-20-foot (18.3 m × 6.1 m) cast-iron plunge bath and five slipper baths. Northwich Public Baths was built in 1913 following subsidence at Verdin Park pool. It its doors on 23 January 1991  to be replaced with Moss Farm leisure complex
column22: which in turn was replaced by Memorial Court entertainment and leisure venue in 2015.

column1: == Landmarks and religious sites ==

The parish church is known as St. Helen's Witton. It is a Grade I Listed Building. The church initially developed as a chapel of ease associated with the parish of Great Budworth to serve the local community
column2: known as the Chapel of Witton. There is no known date for the creation of this chapel
column3: but it is thought to have existed in the 13th century. None of this building exists in the current church. There is no documentary evidence to indicate the dates of the older parts of the current building. However
column4: stones in the fabric of the porch carry inscriptions attributed to "Ricardus Alkoke Capellanus". This name matches documents concerning land in Northwich and Lostock Gralam dated 1468
column5: but this cannot be used to date the church accurately.It was not until 7 August 1900 that the parish of Witton (otherwise Northwich) was formed from parts of Great Budworth

column1: The present St Wilfrid's (Roman Catholic) church was built in 1866. The current Northwich Methodist Chapel was opened in 1990
column2: but there has been a Methodist presence in the town at least since 1774
column3: when John Wesley laid the foundation stone of the first chapel in the London Road area.

column1: The Northwich Union Workhouse opened in 1837 following the Poor Law Amendment of 1834 that standardised the system of poor relief throughout Britain. The building is now the Weaver Hall Museum.

The Dock Road Edwardian Pumping Station is a Grade II Listed Building originally built by Northwich Urban District Council in 1913. For over 60 years it was used for pumping sewage from parts of Northwich to the Wallerscote Treatment Works. Before it was built
column2: untreated sewage was discharged directly into the River Weaver
column3: causing widespread pollution.

column1: Two swing bridges
column2: Hayhurst Bridge built in 1898
column3: and Town Bridge built in 1899
column4: cross the Weaver at Northwich. The bridges were the first two electrically powered swing bridges in Great Britain and were built on floating pontoons to counteract the mine subsidence. They were designed by Colonel John Saner.

column1: The Floatel Northwich was moored on the Weaver near the confluence of the two rivers
column2: but was closed when the owners
column3: The Real Hotel Company plc
column4: went into administration in January 2009. It has since been removed. It was the UK's only floating hotel.

column1: == Transport ==
The key historical mode of transport is water. By 1732 the River Weaver was improved from Frodsham Bridge to Winsford Bridge and eventually allowed vessels up to 160 tonnes (160
column2: 000 kg) to travel up to Northwich Bridge. The Trent and Mersey Canal
column3: opened in 1775
column4: passed to the north of Northwich because of objections from the trustees of the Weaver Navigation. However
column5: the canal passed salt deposits near the village of Marston
column6: and many of the later salt mines were based along its banks including the Lion Salt Works. The Anderton Boat Lift was opened in 1875 to connect the canal and river systems. It was fully restored in 2002 and now houses a visitor centre.The road system around Northwich can be dated back to the Roman times. The A556 and A559 follow the route of the Roman road that runs from Chester to York. The A556 diverts away from the route of the Roman road following a new route to the south of the town acting as the town's bypass. The Chester to Manchester road became a Turnpike in 1769. The A530
column8: also passes near to the town
column9: and this follows the route of the Roman road that connected Warrington and Middlewich. The old route to Warrington and the north from Middlewich
column11: was replaced by a new route through Knutsford
column12: which became a turnpike in 1753. Northwich is connected to the motorway network to the north of the town via the A559 onto the M56 motorway; and to the east of the town via the A556 at Junction 19 of the M6 motorway.

column1: The railway came to the town in 1863 when the Cheshire Midland Railway constructed its line from Knutsford. The West Cheshire Railway built its line to Helsby in 1869. Passenger trains from Northwich to Chester via Delamere commenced in 1875. The route through Northwich is now marketed as the Mid-Cheshire line. Northwich railway station
column2: last rebuilt in 1897
column3: is on the line from Chester to Manchester Piccadilly. There are also stations within close vicinity at Greenbank
column4: also on the Mid-Cheshire line
column5: and Hartford (on the West Coast Main Line).

column1: There are bus routes between Northwich and a number of local towns
column2: and villages including Weaverham
column3: Hartford
column4: Crewe
column5: Warrington
column6: Kelsall and Chester.Family run coach company
column9: before being taken over by Holmeswood Coaches; who still run the Northwich depot.

column1: == Education ==
Northwich and its surroundings has a number of schools and colleges. Sir John Deane's College is now a sixth form college
column2: but was originally formed as a grammar school in 1557. The school was originally known as Witton Grammar School and was erected close to Witton Chapel. The school moved to its current location
column3: to the south of the town
column4: in 1907–08. The Grange School
column5: Northwich is an independent school.

column1: Primary education include:
The Grange Junior School
Witton Church Walk CofE Primary School
Victoria Road Primary School
Charles Darwin Community Primary School
Winnington Park Community Primary and Nursery School
St. Wilfrid's Catholic Primary School
Hartford Manor Primary School
Hartford County Primary School
Kingsmead Primary School was shortlisted for the Prime Minister's Better Public Building award in 2005.

Rosebank School is a school for autistic children aged 3–11 years.During the 19th century many new schools were founded and by 1850 twelve 'academies' were recorded in the area. The town is now served by County High School Leftwich
column2: a specialist media arts college
column3: while University of Chester Academy Northwich
column4: a specialist performing arts college and Hartford High School both admit pupils from Northwich. There are also several primary schools in the area. St. Nicholas Catholic High School is also in the local vicinity
column5: and performs well on national exam boards
column6: coming second in the whole of Cheshire.

column1: Mid Cheshire College had its main campus in nearby Hartford
column2: offering further education courses. The campus closed in 2018 after it merged with Warrington Collegiate a year earlier to form Warrington and Vale Royal CollegeIn November 2005
column3: as part of the Northwich Vision
column4: a refurbishment of the town's railway station included a Centre called Zone that promotes lifelong learning by offering people the opportunity to access a range of online and taught courses.
